segments.text: Hello, welcome to a new video series about chatbots.
So this series is going to find itself in my Programming
with Text course, which I started about a year ago
and made a whole bunch of videos for.
And now a year later, I want to add some content to it.
And so what I want to add is about chatbots.
So I want to, OK, so first of all, what is a chatbot?
So I'm going to use the Wikipedia definition, which
says, a chatbot is a computer program which
conducts a conversation via auditory or textual methods.
So this is the kind of thing that's
already in a lot of my examples, where users are typing in text
and it gets processed and some other text comes out,
maybe on a web page.
I have this whole series on Twitter bots.
Those Twitter bots you could consider chatbots.
That conversation might be just one way.
It's a bot that just tweets once an hour,
says something to the audience, nobody replies.
Or it could be a one-to-many conversation,
where any time somebody tweets at the Twitter bot,
the bot replies with something.
It could be two bots talking to each other.
So chatbot is, this is a broader term than things
that I've actually looked at before.
I've just looked at specific kinds of chatbots
without mentioning the word chatbot.
So now what I do is say, well, what if we really
think about a computer program having
a conversation with a human?
And can we achieve that in the browser with open source tools?
Can we also then, once we do that, think about,
oh, we could make stuff for a commercial medium,
like Twitter.
Or it could be a voice conversational interface
with, hello, Siri.
Apparently, these markers are not smart markers.
Somebody will invent that, though, where
I can just ask my marker a question with no problem.
Alexa, Expo, what is the weather today in New York?
OK.
So apparently, my little Expo whiteboard spray marker,
it would have been nice if this was really spontaneous.
But I did this earlier, and now I'm
remaking this video trying to make this joke spontaneous.
It's not working.
OK.
So I forgot that I had a presentation that I was doing.
A chatbot is a computer program which
conducts a conversation via auditory or textual methods.
So I want to get to all this stuff.
I want to look at some open source tools,
make stuff happen in the browser.
I want to see, can we do stuff with voice and speech
recognition?
Can we interface with human?
Can we interface with commercial products
that I'm now apparently buzz marketing for free,
albeit absurdly, in this video?
So there's a long history of this tradition of computers
having conversations.
And by no means is this I'm now about to give you
a presentation of the history of this.
And I'll try to include some links,
in particular, to an article that actually gives you
a history of chatbots.
It's a wonderful article that I'll link to
in this video's description.
But Eliza probably being one of the most famous ones from 1966.
And it simulated conversation using pattern matching
and substitution.
So this is something that I want to talk.
What are the different techniques
for making a chatbot?
How do you determine, how does the bot, the computer program,
understand what the person said?
How does the bot reply?
Is it hard-coded typed replies?
Is it machine learning neural network generated replies?
These are some things that I want to explore in these videos.
Another famous example is Alice from 1995.
Artificial linguistic internet computer entity.
That is the best acronym ever.
But this is why I want to mention Alice,
is with Alice came something called AIML, Artificial
Intelligent Markup Language.
So a markup language, essentially,
for writing a script for a chatbot.
So if the user says this, the chatbot says this.
If the user says this, the chatbot says this.
And the script looks something like this.
So there can be this idea of a pattern,
as well as there can be this idea of setting a topic,
a reply, templates.
This whole kind of, so this is, I
encourage you to investigate this at alicebot.org.
The reason why I'm mentioning this
is my first video is going to start using something
called RiveScript, which is an open source chatbot brain
making tool, kind of similar to, with its own sort of markup
and syntax similar to Alice.
So these are some important considerations.
This is that article that I was referring to,
so I highly recommend you go and read it
if you want to kind of learn a bit about the history of chat
bots and also where this idea of deep learning
and neural networks could possibly fit in,
which I will get to in a future video.
But some things you really want to think about
are the models of conversation.
So retrieval versus generative.
So I'm going to start with retrieval-based systems, which
are much simpler, meaning I just have
like this script of what the bot can say.
And I'm trying to match some sort of pattern of what
the user is saying and reply in a given way,
versus a generative system where I
might have an algorithm that generates what the bot says
in any way whatsoever.
Long versus short conversations.
I want to stick with short conversations.
So how do I make a bot that just can tell a knock-knock joke
or respond to a knock-knock joke?
That's a short conversation.
Or guess a number.
That's actually one of the examples
I'll make in a future video that's already been made.
That's why I'm able to reference it,
about a chat bot that thinks of a number
and you try to guess it.
Open versus closed domain.
So are you making a chat bot that's
like just about ordering a pizza,
versus I am a psychology bot.
And talk to me about any of your problems, and I will respond.
So completely open domain.
So again, I want to start with, to learn about chat bots
and be able to prototype and make things quickly and easily,
I'm going to start with short, closed, retrieval-based
systems.
But hopefully, as this video series expands,
I might be able to investigate generative systems, longer
conversations, more open domain conversations.
And again, a lot of my learning and references about this
came from this wonderful article here.
So RiveScript.
This is where I'm going to start.
I like to try to use open source free things as much as
possible, although I think to really push experiments
in this conversational interface direction, voice
stuff, we're going to have to, at some point,
use some things made by large companies
and interface with their APIs, similar to what
I did with Twitter.
So RiveScript is great because it's a simple scripting
language.
It's based off of this idea of artificial intelligence
markup language, but it's slightly
different and even simpler.
It just has a handful of simple rules.
I'm going to try to go through some of them with you,
but honestly, I'll show you the page where it just
describes all the rules.
It's the kind of thing you're going to want to read yourself.
It's open source licensed MIT, so you
can use it for its very liberal open source permissive license.
And you can use it with a variety of programming
languages, Go, Java, JavaScript, Perl, Python, maybe more.
But so I'm going to use it with JavaScript.
So in the next, if you keep watching this,
this is my last.
Look at this.
I made a slide presentation.
Aren't I a good presenter of things on the internet
with my slide presentation?
So if you continue to watch these videos,
we'll have a slide presentation again.
I will start by just talking you through the basics
of RiveScript.
I will then make a look at using RiveScript in the browser
with JavaScript.
And eventually, I'm going to look at it with a library
called p5 speech, which allows me to use speech to text
and text to speech from the browser,
and then eventually move past that as well.
So I hope you watch some of these chatbot videos
and make some stuff.
And give me your feedback.
Thank you.
